text: OK, the tape is rolling. OK, first of all, could you tell me if you, as a youngster, did you come from the fan structure in science fiction? No, my experience with science fiction was very solitary for most of my period of growing up. I discovered the area of the fantastic. I think I can trace back to when I was eight or nine years old when I found some old Edgar Rice Burroughs novels in my grandmother's back closet and one by one read them and became entranced by it. That was followed by a, period during the thirties, when the pulp adventure magazines were at their height. And my father and his brothers, my uncles, would buy these 10-cent magazines and bring them home and I would read them. Mostly they seemed to prefer the pulp hero magazines like Doc Savage and operator number five and the spider and the shadow and magazines of this kind of which I, you know, G8 is battle laces. But eventually I discovered a secondhand magazine store in Kansas City where I was born and grew up. And when I finished reading the magazines, I'd take them down to this magazine store and trade them for science fiction magazines, which I then devoured. so I grew up not really knowing any other science fiction readers my brother, older brother, read a little but not with the enthusiasm that I did so my first contact with other readers, much less other writers was after I'd been writing for four years I was aware that there was this fan structure because in some of the magazines like Startling Stories and Thrilling Wonder Stories and even in Astounding, there would be letter columns with the names of people. Gradually, I began to recognize a few of them and I realized that there were other readers, but it wasn't until I attended the World Science Fiction Convention of 1952 which was held in Chicago and I was urged to go by the company I worked for at that time a paperback publishing house for whom I was supposed to be their science fiction expert and they suggested they pay my way if I went to the 60-80 miles down from Racine, Wisconsin to Chicago and attend the convention to make contacts and that was my first experience with really meeting other readers and other writers and agents and editors and the whole paraphernalia of the science fiction world. Okay, good. Can you recall the circumstances? I believe it was in 1949, of your first published story. Yes, I had read science fiction, as I said, from oh about the age of 8 or 9, and read it seriously for a while during the middle 30s. And at the age of oh about 15 or 16 I had written some science fiction stories, though with no particular skill, and I usually, like most beginning writers, didn't even finish most of them. I can only remember one that I finished. But then the college came along, and the war came along, and I got involved in both of them, and it wasn't until after I'd come back from service and gotten my bachelor's degree and had actually had about a year of graduate study, that I decided to try full-time writing. I had been interested in theater, playwriting, but I decided I didn't want to get a degree in that in the speech and theater area, but I was fascinated by the notion of radio writing. So I returned from Northwestern University to Kansas City with the notion of writing a series of half-hour radio dramas based on Kansas City history and getting some local radio station to produce them. And I actually wrote four of these and did the research for them and so forth, and then went around to the radio stations and found out that not any of them were interested. so i had a wife to sport and i sat down and wrote the kind of thing that i've been reading all this time first time seriously and wrote a story called paradox which i sent off to astounding and astounding set it back then i sent it off to amazing and amazing set it back And I sent it off to Thrilling Wonder Stories, which was the third magazine that had been unstarved in stories that were published by the same chain. And one day I got a letter back saying, I like your story, Paradox, and I'll pay you $80 for it. So I thought, marvelous. I'd really stumbled onto something that was tremendous. And so I meanwhile had been writing another story, which was a story called Communication, and I created it the same way I sent it off to Astounding first and I think maybe I sent it off second after I got rejected by Astounding to Throwing Wonder Stories and the same editor Sam Merwin Jr. bought it and that was the story which happened to be published first in Startling Stories in September of 1949 where the first story I actually wrote which is Paradox, was published the following month in Thrilling Wonder Stories in October. You didn't have to go through a long process of getting rejection slips then, did you? No, as a matter of fact, sometimes when I talk to aspiring young writers, and they turn to me and they say, how many rejection slips did you get before you finally sold a story? And I look a little sheepish, because I know it's not the answer they want. And I said, I sold the first story I ever really wrote seriously. And their faces fall. And then I follow it up immediately by saying, but of course Ray Bradbury had 75 to 100 stories rejected before he sold one. And look what he got to. Yeah, okay. This next question, I'm not quite sure how to phrase it, But I've always been fascinated by the split in your relationship to science fiction. You know, it seems to me that you must have at one time made a decision to be an academic and to be a writer at the same time. I wonder if that was a hard decision or if you ever considered full-time writing. I did, as a matter of fact, write full-time for a period of a little more than three years, It was a year in 1948, 49, and I went back to school then and got a master's degree, but I continued to write. And then after I'd worked for this paperback publisher, after I got my master's degree, worked for a paperback publisher for a year and a half, I found out that I'd sold four stories that I hadn't known about and decided to go back to full-time writing. So I did write full-time from the fall of 1942 until the late summer of 1955. And really much of the groundwork for the later books that I published and the success that I had, I think, such as it was based upon that freelance period. I didn't make a lot of money at it, below the poverty level, but my needs were fairly simple at that time and what it later paid off in the sense that the stories that I wrote appeared in books and some of them even were made in the movies and all that sort of thing. And if I'd had the money for them at the time I was writing them, I would have thought I was very well off indeed. But it was after 1955, or in the fall of 1955, after my wife and I had moved back to Lawrence, Kansas, simply as a place to live, but I got involved, almost by accident, with teaching at the university from which I'd gotten my two degrees at the University of Kansas, and became involved with other aspects of the university, edited the alumni magazine for three years, and then became director of public relations for the university for 12 years before returning to full-time teaching and writing in 1970. But looking back upon it, I know, I think right from the beginning, I had the feeling that I wanted to do criticism in the area. My first 10 stories, for instance, were published under a pseudonym of Edwin James. I began to use my own name with the 11th story. But the reason that I can remember now for doing that was the fact that I thought I would write criticism about science fiction and I wanted to save my real name for that. But after 10 stories, I decided that was foolish. and I ought to use my real name for everything. But looking back upon it, I think the academic interest was there right from the beginning. Okay, that's interesting. I want to ask you, obviously, a couple questions, at least on your criticism. But first, could you give me sort of a brief overview of the things that you do at the University of Kansas that involve science fiction? I imagine it's probably one of the most active university science fiction programs in the country, if not the most active. We have a lot of things going on. I've been fortunate to have found a colleague here, Stephen Goldman, who is interested in science fiction, although his basic academic discipline is the medieval, period. it's a strange phenomenon. I think that a great many science fiction academicians have their expertise as medievalists. I don't know what the connection is, but I suspect that there is one. But we also, because of our interest here, I think have attracted some graduate students who are interested in the area, some of whom have gotten degrees not in science fiction because we don't offer one, but in science fiction-related areas. I have one graduate student now who's doing his dissertation on my work and another one who graduated last year who did a creative dissertation of a book of science fiction stories. So we have had that body of graduate students who have taught science fiction classes at the sophomore level as one of the required courses in composition and literature. And I also traditionally teach a science fiction course, an undergraduate and graduate science fiction course each year, although my primary duties in the English department are the teaching of fiction writing. Perhaps our most interesting science fiction offering, however, is the three-week Intensive English Institute on the teaching of science fiction that we offer in the summer. we realized a number of years ago that there were a lot of people faced with the task sometimes self-assumed sometimes assigned of teaching a science fiction course and they were largely unprepared because there had been no academic program on science fiction certainly not on the teaching of science fiction So we set up this intensive three-week workshop to offer teachers the opportunity to attend and get a six-credit-hour program in science fiction, all aspects of science fiction, in just three weeks. It's a very intensive experience. We bring in several science fiction writers besides myself. This year we're having Gordon Dixon and Theodore Sturgeon and Frederick Poole, and it has been a most successful and satisfying experience. This summer the Institute will be held from July 5th to July 23rd. okay, by the way I am a medievalist myself too that is kind of strange but my field is medieval literature too is that right? why do you think medievalists are attracted to it? I don't know, I never thought of it until you just mentioned it I know half a dozen people Tom Shippey who is an English medievalist who teaches now at Leeds University I know the editor of Pocketbook Science Fiction, David Hartwell, is a medievalist with a Ph.D. in medieval literature, and I think there must be a number of others. And I think my own feeling is that medieval literature perhaps requires the same kind of world construction. of imagination, and, you know, building up an entirely new world out of different concepts, much like science fiction. At least that's the theory that I'm proposing. Well, that's interesting. Yeah, okay, I never thought of it. Okay, listen, we teach a class here at Odessa College, and we use the Road to Science Fiction series, which I consider to be a very valuable and unique endeavor. Thank you. It's something we needed. I'd like to ask you just a couple questions on that. First of all, for that particular approach to science fiction, was there any kind of impetus or idea that caused you to start that series? Maybe it'd be best to give you a kind of history of its development. I had, when I first went back to full-time teaching, had been asked if I would teach a science fiction course, which is different from the experience at most universities where there is some resistance to the notion of doing that. And I accepted because I had the feeling that there wasn't a good history of science fiction and that this course would give me the incentive to write it. So I sat down and wrote very fast and ended up with 13 chapters representing about 13 lectures for the 14-week semester. And these chapters, or these lectures, became the 13 chapters in a book of mine, which appeared in about, I guess it was 75, after some delays, as alternate world the Illustrated History of Science Fiction. And it did reasonably well. There were some problems with its publication and so forth, including the delays. But it is still remembered today in spite of being out of print as being one of the best histories of science fiction, complementing Brian Aldis' Billion-Year Spree, which he was doing at the same time, but his book came out a couple years earlier but as one consequence of its publication I got a call one day from an editor at New American Library who was admiring it and asked me if I'd like to do a book for them My initial reaction was that I felt that we needed a good collection of essays about science fiction and I proposed a book of these rather fortunately I think for me it was turned down at Numerican Library and they said they'd rather have some stories and I knew also that that I really felt the need for anthologies which covered more than the brief span of the 20s to the 60s which most anthologies did, and there really wasn't much in the 20s or 30s, most of it covered the period of the 40s and 50s. So I said yes, and I sent them a proposal for the first volume of the Road Science Fiction. At that time, all we knew that there would be would be one volume, which covered the period from the earliest prehistory of literature, not to mention science fiction, up to 1900, and the H.G. Wells' early stories and novels. By the time I got finished with the manuscript, I had felt that it really, unlike most books, came out even better than I thought it was going to, and I propose that we go ahead with a second and third volume. They said, let's wait and see how this does, and eventually, after it had done better than they thought, they agreed that I could go on to volume 2 and 3, which covered the period from 1900 to approximately 1940, and then from 1940 to 1970 or 70, actually the latest one, 76 I think. And I did those together, but by the time I got to the third volume, I realized that I wasn't going to be able to get in everything that I wanted and suggested we go ahead and do a fourth volume. But they said, well, let's wait and see how these do. As a consequence, however, of the fact that these did very well, or well accepted. They finally agreed that I could go ahead and do a fourth volume, and I've just completed that, sent in the manuscript, and the fourth volume Road to Science Fiction is scheduled to appear in October of this year, and it will cover the period overlapping a little bit with Volume 3, the period from 1950 to 1981. The last volume is going to be a little different from the first three, however. The first three are on a historical basis, as I've indicated, and you have noted, with much of the emphasis being on the development of science fiction and the stories generally selected or the ones which were important in the development of science fiction or typical of a certain period or a certain style. In the more current story, this is much more difficult to determine. You can't really say what stories are important until much after they've been published, and you can't certainly say which are typical until you decide what the period really stands for. So what I did in the fourth volume was to select stories that I thought dealt with the literary uses of science fiction. and so that the volume is primarily concerned not with questions of generic importance but the question of literary uses okay that was a very complete answer in fact you probably got a couple of my next questions with that one let's see could you just say in volume one could you briefly comment on I think the idea or the concept behind that particular volume was that before science fiction could exist, that man had to discover that there was a future and there was such a thing as progress. Could you briefly explain that? Yes, it seems to me that the essential nature of science fiction is that it deals with change. In fact, in order for us to recognize a story or a novel as being science fiction, we have to identify that part of it which is different from here and now. our everyday world. And so it deals with how people would react in changed circumstances. So, up to approximately the time of the Industrial Revolution, the very concept of change itself was alien to human minds. For most of humanity's history, it seems to me, and of course as a medievalist, Maybe I'm venturing into your area. But it seems to me, looking back over the history of humanity, that mostly people saw change as being only the eternal circle of the seasons changing from spring to summer to fall to winter and back again, or if there was change in people's circumstances, it was usually change for the worst. That is, the king would die and the empire would be thrown into turmoil or there would be war lost or run or barbarians would come in pillaging and burning and killing and other kinds of terrible things, or there would be droughts or plagues or all sorts of bad things. But so as a consequence throughout most of man's history that if there have been legends and myths of a golden age which man once existed in and from which humanity has been expelled or has degenerated or deteriorated. And it wasn't until the investor revolution and, of course, the scientific perceptions that preceded it and accompanied it, and which began to create change that people saw could be beneficial. over which they might be able to exercise some control. That is, it was man-made change created by human desires and intelligence, and it could be controlled by humanity's exercise of intelligence. And it seems to me that science fiction was the literary response to that recognition. fine okay um i've noted that in each volume you seem to have a you know a unifying concept like for the second volume it would be the idea that that man had to consider himself as a species right in science fiction the third was that uh we have to have an open mind about the universe and man's fate for science fiction to exist uh does the fourth volume have that kind of unifying idea behind it and what would it be? No, what it deals with and those themes really kind of happened in the first three volumes and when you run into coincidences like that you feel like something is going right it really happened when I wrote the first introduction to, or the introduction to volume one, and I realized as I wrote this introduction that I was setting down three basic requirements and that these basic requirements for the existence of science fiction, the recognition of humanity as a species and so forth, somehow fit in with my concept of how science fiction had developed. And so from there, I picked it up for volume two and volume three. But I think in this current one, the genre already has been established by the time we come to 1950, and that now the major considerations are not generic so much as how are we going to write it? How are we going to express the ideas, and what ideas are we going to express, considering the fact that we already have a genre to deal with? How are the first three volumes sold? Reasonably well. For this kind of book, the mentor books at New American Library are intended to be primarily academic books. They also issue them on the mass market, but they don't expect a major sale on them. And all three of them, at the present time, or as of six months ago, all three of them have already sold over 30,000 copies each. And they will keep them in print sometime, expect to sell more, of course, particularly with the issuance of the fourth volume. but they expect, you know, the average mentor book only sells about 20,000, so it's already done, you know, all of it's done 50% better than the average book. This is sort of a general question. Feel free to answer it as briefly as you'd like. Why do you think there's a need? I think you do think there is, a need for science fiction, criticism, and scholarship. I think that a category of fiction like science fiction, I hate to continue to use the word genre because it's not really traditionally a genre. It is a set of conventions and a set of expectations. But in this particular area, which has largely been ignored by the apparatus of criticism in this country and in other parts of the world as well, because it's not been considered important enough to merit criticism. It's considered to be a pulp literature, a popular literature, and in a sense beneath criticism. And as a consequence, it has developed largely under its own impetus without any kinds of efforts of critical minds to look at it and try to appraise it, say, what's good and what's bad according to some kind of standards that can be established, and as well to teach, to help the other critical areas of English literature to appraise it differently, to understand that unlike other kinds of literature, science fiction has special things that it does and has special ways that it does it, and to appraise science fiction by the same kinds of standards that you apply to traditional literature, science fiction is always going to come up short. It doesn't do the same things. It deals not with characters, but with change. And so it seems to me that there needs to be two different routes, or there are two desirable ends for criticism. One is to educate the non-science fiction part of the literary world to the special requirements of science fiction and its special accomplishments. The other is to exercise and apply a set of standards to science fiction itself to improve the breed, so to speak. Okay, fine. I only have two more questions on this particular line that I've been following. Your book, Alternate Worlds, I didn't have a real specific question on that. I've used it as a research aid, and found it very useful. Of course, I read Brian Aldis's and Donald Walheim's and so forth, histories of science fiction. Do you think there's room for any more histories of science fiction? Well, they're still coming out. And, you know, whether there are any more needed, I suspect that as these books get dated, new appraisals are necessary. And indeed, if a new kind of perception of science fiction emerges, there certainly needs to be a reappraisal of the history that is to either support it or refute it. I don't know that we really need more history. I suspect that maybe in another 10 or 15 years, maybe a new history will be more needed. Fine, okay, my other question this is one we ask all of the authors that we talk to and it's sort of a touchy subject with them it has to do with the relation between science fiction and mainstream I read some of your ideas on it and I can't quite make up my mind I think in one essay I think it was the one that appeared in Bretner's book you said that science fiction and the mainstream were becoming closer but that you thought that perhaps it would be a good idea for science fiction to keep its unique qualities. Whereas in another piece, I think it was the introduction to Breaking Point, you said or implied that it was a good idea that they do come back together where they belong and that they should blend. I wondered if you could specify your feelings about that. Well, I guess maybe I do have mixed notions about it. I think that existing separately, science fiction, has attained certain kinds of strengths created by isolation, but also certain kinds of weaknesses. But I also think that the mainstream of literature has certain qualities and selection processes that could benefit science fiction. I guess the ideal, and I think in a certain sense it is happening, the ideal would be that good books ought to be published essentially without generic identification. And they are being so published. I think if you look around at the significant new novels that are really selling well, like the Dune books or like Gregory Benford's newest novel, Timescape, they aren't really published generically. They are being published as novels which can find their own readers. And as a consequence, the latest, I guess, God Emperor of Doom, sold something like 200,000 copies in hardcover, which makes it a best-selling. It certainly would not have that kind of sales as a science fiction book, and it is not being published that way. At the same time, I would say that I would hate to see the genre itself. be totally merged into the mainstream so that it couldn't be identified because I think it has certain kinds of strengths that might well be lost. And if every book wasn't able to seek a particular kind of audience that could identify it, there would be much less science fiction written and much less read. So I'd like to see both things happen simultaneously. I think they are happening. It also has some drawbacks to it, too, currently, in that if science fiction has the capacity to sell as bestsellers, then editors and publishers are going to be looking at all books that are submitted to them, all science fiction books, to see if they have the best seller in them. And many, I think, mid-range books, which once would have been published without question, are now being rejected because they do not really have the potential to be as rewarding as some of the others. Okay. If you're still doing okay, I think I better move on to some of your own work. Fine. I did have some more ideas about the criticism and so forth, but I better be selective here because I did want to talk about your own work too. The joymakers. I guess it's hedonics, how you pronounce it. That's how I pronounce it. Right, okay. If I remember, their premise was that the basic freedom is the freedom to be happy. Mm-hmm. Okay, now, obviously, I read the book and I know the answer to this, but could you just briefly tell me where the flaw is in that reasoning? Well, and I really worked my way through it, having gotten the idea for a basic science of happiness, from an article I read in the Encyclopedia Britannica and sort of work my way through the notion that happiness, you know, could be achieved scientifically, directly rather than through things that we think might make us happy, like love or fame or money or success or whatever we think, you know, might make us happy. and essentially, this article that I read pointed out to me something that I don't know whether I would have thought about or not. Maybe I would have, that there are basically two ways to be happy. You can either get what you want, which will make you happy, or you can want what you get, and that means that you have to discipline yourself so that no matter what happens, you're happy because you are the kind of disciplined person who doesn't let his happiness depend upon external events. And that, of course, is a kind of stoicism. And I saw this as being the two holes upon which I could rest a philosophic approach to the notion of happiness. ultimately as it worked out in the novel it turned out that the people who wanted happiness to get what they want since the what one can get in the external world is limited by the number of people and the number of people who want this particular thing ultimately they get what they want by being fed illusions that they get what they want and ultimately everybody ends up floating in amniotic cells living on dreams of success and accomplishment fed by a machine which eventually works out to be that you're happy when you don't want anything anymore and it occurred to me that that is the same as death and ultimately the equation for that, is that happiness equals death, and that life is still wanting something. Okay, as I was nearing the end of that book, and saw what you were getting at, I got the impression that you were saying man was not meant, or he was not created to be satisfied, his nature is not such, and I wondered if you... Yeah, well certainly my feeling about it comes in a sense from a story about Candide, which I read many years ago, that Candide was walking along a country road and saw a woman, and I don't mean Candide, I mean Voltaire, the author of Candide. Voltaire was walking along this country road and saw a peasant woman working in the field, singing happily while he was walking along, overcome with the cares of state and the problems of intellectual difficulties, and he said to himself, wouldn't it be wonderful if I could change places with her and she could have all of my knowledge and misery and I could have all of her ignorance and happiness? And he responded, no. He said, I wouldn't trade that for an instant. He said, if the choice is happiness versus knowledge, He said, I'll choose knowledge every time. And it seems to me that people only think they want to be happy. That what they really want is knowledge. Not just abstract knowledge. They want knowledge, and they will pursue knowledge even when it makes them unhappy. And I have incorporated this in a number of books. Campus, for instance, has the same kind of theme. I also got the impression, though, maybe I was wrong here in the work Faust I think that the bargain Faust makes with the devil is that if the devil can ever satisfy and make him totally happy then he's lost and he goes to hell you didn't have that in the background either? no, I don't think so of course I know the Faust legend and the various literary works based upon it But I wasn't really thinking of Faust at that time. What I was really thinking of more than anything else was the fact that it was the Voltaire concept and the feeling that people, I guess the basics, my own basic feeling, that people only think they want to be happy. Okay, let me just move on briefly to the immortals. would I be right in presuming that to be your best known book? Well probably because of the television series it may be the best known although certainly the listeners is also very well known. What was your reaction to the TV series? Oh I thought it was a total disaster and that's not uncommon of course but the resemblances between the novel and the book are very slight. My book starts with the immortal being a drifter who comes in and sells a pint of blood and then disappears for the rest of the novel until the very end. And the television series is all about the immortal and his being pursued, and eventually it turns into simply another search for the papers another fugitive somebody is being chased but it makes no real difference why he's being chased he's being, could have been he had a fortune or a secret or a Maltese falcon or anything else okay listen and David was...

OK, first of all, could you tell me if you, as a youngster, did you come from the fan structure in science fiction?
No, my experience with science fiction was very solitary for most of my period of growing up.
I discovered the area of the fantastic.
I think I can trace back to when I was eight or nine years old
when I found some old Edgar Rice Burroughs novels
in my grandmother's back closet
and one by one read them and became entranced by it.
That was followed by a,
period during the thirties, when the pulp adventure magazines were at their height.
And my father and his brothers, my uncles, would buy these 10-cent magazines and bring
them home and I would read them. Mostly they seemed to prefer the pulp hero magazines like
Doc Savage and operator number five and the spider and the shadow and magazines of this
kind of which I, you know, G8 is battle laces.
But eventually I discovered a secondhand magazine store in Kansas City where I was born
and grew up.
And when I finished reading the magazines, I'd take them down to this magazine store
and trade them for science fiction magazines, which I then devoured.

other writers

Stories and even in Astounding, there would be letter columns with the names of people.
Gradually, I began to recognize a few of them and I realized that there were other readers,

down

with really meeting other readers and other writers and agents and editors
and the whole paraphernalia of the science fiction world.
Okay, good.
Can you recall the circumstances?
I believe it was in 1949, of your first published story.
Yes, I had read science fiction, as I said, from oh about the age of 8 or 9,
and read it seriously for a while during the middle 30s.
And at the age of oh about 15 or 16 I had written some science fiction stories,
though with no particular skill,
and I usually, like most beginning writers,
didn't even finish most of them.
I can only remember one that I finished.
But then the college came along,
and the war came along,
and I got involved in both of them,
and it wasn't until after I'd come back from service
and gotten my bachelor's degree
and had actually had about a year of graduate study,
that I decided to try full-time writing.
I had been interested in theater, playwriting,
but I decided I didn't want to get a degree in that
in the speech and theater area,
but I was fascinated by the notion of radio writing.
So I returned from Northwestern University to Kansas City
with the notion of writing a series of half-hour radio dramas
based on Kansas City history
and getting some local radio station to produce them.
And I actually wrote four of these
and did the research for them and so forth,
and then went around to the radio stations
and found out that not any of them were interested.
so i had a wife to sport and i sat down and wrote the kind of thing that i've been reading all this
time first time seriously and wrote a story called paradox which i sent off to astounding
and astounding set it back then i sent it off to amazing and amazing set it back
And I sent it off to Thrilling Wonder Stories,
which was the third magazine that had been unstarved in stories
that were published by the same chain.
And one day I got a letter back saying,
I like your story, Paradox, and I'll pay you $80 for it.
So I thought, marvelous.
I'd really stumbled onto something that was tremendous.
And so I meanwhile had been writing another story,
which was a story called Communication,
and I

I sent it off to Astounding first
and I think maybe I sent it off
second

by Astounding
to
Throwing Wonder Stories

and
that was the story

in
Startling Stories

where the first story
I actually wrote
which is Paradox, was published the following month in Thrilling Wonder Stories in October.
You didn't have to go through a long process of getting rejection slips then, did you?
No, as a matter of fact, sometimes when I talk to aspiring young writers,
and they turn to me and they say,
how many rejection slips did you get before you finally sold a story?
And I look a little sheepish, because I know it's not the answer they want.
And I said, I sold the first story I ever really wrote seriously.
And their faces fall.
And then I follow it up immediately by saying,
but of course Ray Bradbury had 75 to 100 stories rejected before he sold one.
And look what he got to.
Yeah, okay.
This next question, I'm not quite sure how to phrase it,
But I've always been fascinated by the split in your relationship to science fiction.
You know, it seems to me that you must have at one time made a decision to be an academic and to be a writer at the same time.
I wonder if that was a hard decision or if you ever considered full-time writing.
I did, as a matter of fact, write full-time for a period of a little more than three years,
It was a year in 1948, 49, and I went back to school then and got a master's degree,
but I continued to write.
And then after I'd worked for this paperback publisher, after I got my master's degree,
worked for a paperback publisher for a year and a half, I found out that I'd sold four
stories that I hadn't known about and decided to go back to full-time writing. So I did
write full-time from the fall of 1942 until the late summer of 1955. And really much of the
groundwork for the later books that I published and the success that I had, I think, such as it
was based upon that freelance period.
I didn't make a lot of money at it,
below the poverty level,
but my needs were fairly simple at that time
and what it later paid off
in the sense that the stories that I wrote
appeared in books
and some of them even were made in the movies
and all that sort of thing.
And if I'd had the money for them
at the time I was writing them,
I would have thought I was very well off indeed.
But it was after 1955, or in the fall of 1955,
after my wife and I had moved back to Lawrence, Kansas,
simply as a place to live, but I got involved,
almost by accident, with teaching at the university
from which I'd gotten my two degrees at the University of Kansas,
and became involved with other aspects of the university,
edited the alumni magazine for three years,
and then became director of public relations for the university for 12 years
before returning to full-time teaching and writing in 1970.
But looking back upon it, I know, I think right from the beginning,
I had the feeling that I wanted to do criticism in the area.
My first 10 stories, for instance, were published under a pseudonym of Edwin James.
I began to use my own name with the 11th story.
But the reason that I can remember now for doing that
was the fact that I thought I would write criticism about science fiction
and I wanted to save my real name for that.
But after 10 stories, I decided that was foolish.
and I ought to use my real name for everything.
But looking back upon it,
I think the academic interest was there right from the beginning.
Okay, that's interesting.

although his basic academic discipline is the medieval, period.
it's a strange phenomenon.
I think that a great many science fiction academicians

and another one who graduated last year who did a creative dissertation
of a book of science fiction stories.
So we have had that body of graduate students who have taught science fiction classes at the sophomore level
as one of the required courses in composition and literature.

although my primary duties in the English department are the teaching of fiction writing.
Perhaps our most interesting science fiction offering, however,
is the three-week Intensive English Institute on the teaching of science fiction that we offer in the summer.
we realized a number of years ago

This is sort of a general question.
Feel free to answer it as briefly as you'd like.
Why do you think there's a need?
I think you do think there is, a need for science fiction, criticism, and scholarship.
I think that a category of fiction like science fiction, I hate to continue to use the word
genre because it's not really traditionally a genre.
It is a set of conventions and a set of expectations.

But in this particular area, which has largely been ignored by the apparatus of criticism in this country and in other parts of the world as well, because it's not been considered important enough to merit criticism.
It's considered to be a pulp literature, a popular literature, and in a sense beneath
criticism.
And as a consequence, it has developed largely under its own impetus without any kinds of
efforts of critical minds to look at it and try to appraise it, say, what's good and what's
bad according to some kind of standards that can be established, and as well to teach,
to help the other critical areas of English literature to appraise it differently, to
understand that unlike other kinds of literature, science fiction has special things that it
does and has special ways that it does it, and to appraise science fiction by the same
kinds of standards that you apply to traditional literature, science fiction is always going
to come up short.
It doesn't do the same things.
It deals not with characters, but with change.
And so it seems to me that there needs to be two different routes,
or there are two desirable ends for criticism.
One is to educate the non-science fiction part of the literary world
to the special requirements of science fiction
and its special accomplishments.
The other is to exercise and apply a set of standards
to science fiction itself
to improve the breed, so to speak.

Well, I guess maybe I do have mixed notions about it.
I think that existing separately, science fiction, has attained certain kinds of strengths created by isolation, but also certain kinds of weaknesses.

I guess the ideal, and I think in a certain sense it is happening,
the ideal would be that good books ought to be published
